ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TRIBUNAL FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF PARENTS


    1. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Community Development whether the implementation of the Tribunal to hear cases on parents' maintenance is progressing smoothly.

     The Minister for Community Development (Mr Abdullah Tarmugi): Mr Speaker, I would like to report that the Tribunal for the Maintenance of Parents began operation on 1st June this year. 12 members,

Column: 564

including the President, Mr K S Rajah, have been appointed to serve on the Tribunal.

    The Tribunal meets once a week on Thursday mornings. As at 15th September, 1996, 10 sittings have been held for either mention or hearing. The number of applications has dropped from 74 in June to 23 in July and to 16 in August. Only five applications were registered in the first two weeks of September.

    The Tribunal adopts a non-adversarial approach in settling disputes on maintenance issues within the family. Conciliation Officers in the Tribunal conduct mediation between parties to help them reach a settlement in a more amicable way. When the parties are unable to make a settlement, a hearing will be scheduled for the Tribunal to make an order to determine the outcome of applications.

    65 applications for maintenance have been presented before the Tribunal since it convened its proceedings at the end of June 1996. 35 of these applications have been settled 28 were maintenance orders, five were dismissed applications, one application was withdrawn and no order was made for maintenance for one application. The other applications are in various stages of proceedings.

    Of the 28 maintenance orders made by the Tribunal, 17 applications were successfully settled through mediation, in other words, they were not even heard. The full legal provisions of the Act are thus being tested.

    The experience is still new to the Ministry and the Tribunal and the officers are fine-tuning the work processes as well as their conciliation techniques. They are also learning from the experiences of the Courts. I assure Members of this House that my Ministry and the Tribunal are closely monitoring the situation and will take the necessary steps to educate all parties involved on the purpose of the Tribunal and their rights at the appropriate junctures.

Column: 565



     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what is the waiting time for the cases to be heard by the Tribunal. The other supplementary question is: what are the future plans to integrate the work of the Tribunal with the Family Court?

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: Sir, as I mentioned earlier, of the 65 applications presented since the Tribunal began its first hearing at the end of June, some are still being heard and are in various stages of proceedings. The Tribunal would try to attend to the cases as soon as it can but it would depend on the difficulties and complexities of the cases.

    With regard to whether the Tribunal will be integrated with the courts, I think it is a bit too early to tell. We are just five months into the implementation of the Act and we will wait for some time before we consider the question of integration.

LOWERING OF FOREIGN MAID LEVY


    2. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for Labour whether his Ministry will consider lowering the foreign maid levy from the current $330, especially for families where mothers work, as lowering of the levy will make it more attractive for them to join the workforce to lessen the burden of the household.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the purpose of the domestic worker levy is to dampen the demand for foreign domestic workers. The Government needs to ensure that the number of foreign domestic workers remains manageable as there are various social and political costs in having a large pool of foreign workers here. With rising income and affluence, more and more Singaporeans are finding it affordable to employ foreign domestic workers as evidenced by the rapid rise in the number of such workers over the years. Even with the levy, there are currently more than 90,000 foreign domestic workers in Singapore. Lowering the levy would send a wrong signal and lead to a surge in demand for foreign domestic workers. This would undermine the Government's efforts to manage the foreign worker population here.

Column: 566



    I would like to inform the Member that the Government encourages married women to work by granting them a tax relief on the domestic worker levy. They can claim a tax relief of twice the amount of levy paid for one foreign domestic worker employed by the married woman or her husband in the preceding year. The tax relief is deductible against the earned income of the married woman. In this way, married women are encouraged to continue working by reducing their cost of employing foreign domestic workers.

    Furthermore, the Government provides working mothers with child care subsidy of up to $150 per month for each child placed in a child care centre. Most families also rely on grandparents or other relatives to help out with child care. Hence, employing a foreign domestic worker is not the only answer to the working woman's need to balance career with household burden.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, can the Minister commit to this House that the current levy of $330 will not be further increased?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, in fact, I have told this House that the domestic worker levy has got to be reviewed from time to time in accordance with the wage increase in Singapore. We have got to keep a certain parity. As wages and incomes in Singapore go up, more and more people will find it affordable to have a foreign domestic worker unless the levy is at the same time adjusted to reflect the rising affluence.

Column: 566

3-ROOM HDB FLATS
(Building)


    3. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the substantial demand for 3-room flats, whether it will be more cost-effective for the Housing and Development Board to build rather than buy back such flats in the open market to sell them to the applicants.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are about 242,000 units of 3-room flats,

Column: 567

making up 35% of the stock of HDB flats. HDB stopped building 3-room flats since 1985 because of the poor demand. Applicants have continued to show a preference for the bigger flats. With an average of 12,000 to 13,000 units of 3-room flats transacted in the resale market each year and HDB's programme to progressively sell suitable 3-room rental flats to sitting tenants, there is sufficient supply to meet the demand for 3-room flats.

    HDB has to be cautious not to create a situation of over-supply of 3-room flats. To build new 3-room flats will increase the already large pool of such flats. This may cause resale prices of 3-room flats to fall.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Sir, does the Minister agree that there is an increase in demand for 3-room flats because more people are eligible to buy these flats, including those who are single and some statutory boards? Because of the strong demand, the resale price of 3-room flats has also increased. Right now, the average resale price of a 3-room unit is around $200,000. In time to come, will it be cheaper to build rather than to buy back such flats?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, HDB continues to monitor the resale prices of 3-room flats. Right now, it is still more cost effective for the HDB to buy the units from the resale market and sell them to applicants at a hefty discount, rather than to build new flats, because it costs more to build new flats. HDB will continue to monitor the situation. If it costs us more to buy than to build, then, obviously, we will build. But the objective of making the 3-room flats affordable to Singaporean households will be maintained. The Government is committed to make sure that 90% of Singaporean households will be in a position to afford 3-room flats. I want to assure this House that however high the resale prices of 3-room flats may go, the Government will make sure that 3-room flats will remain affordable to at least 90% of Singaporean households.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Sir, does it mean that the Government will increase the subsidy if the resale price goes up? At

Column: 568

present, the subsidy is $50,000. Does it mean that the Government will revise this amount from time to time if the resale price goes up?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The Government will look at several mechanisms to make sure that the 3-room flats will continue to be affordable to at least 90% of Singaporean households. One solution will be to increase the subsidy. Other solutions may well include extending the mortgage loans and having other financial schemes to make sure that 3-room flats remain affordable.

HALFWAY HOUSES FOR PROBLEM FAMILIES


    4. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Community Development whether the Government will build and operate halfway houses to help problem families who need temporary shelter.

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are six halfway houses or crisis centres in Singapore, and the seventh is in the pipeline. These centres cater to individuals and families in distress and who need temporary shelter. They also cater to children who are abused or in need of care and protection, girls in moral danger, neglected wives and women with marital crisis, battered husbands, men with personality or emotional problems and families with financial or other difficulties.

    Some of these centres also provide support services and social skills training for their clients, eg, counselling, helping victims of abuse, career guidance, job placement and referral to other agencies. Where necessary, my Ministry provides supportive help to individuals and families who need shelter who are referred to by these centres. The help includes financial assistance, job placement, assistance in accommodation and placement of children in schools.

    My Ministry will continue to monitor the need for such centres and will assist VWOs to set up new ones, if necessary. My Ministry will not itself build and operate such halfway houses or crisis centres. VWOs with their specific objective

Column: 569

of providing temporary care and shelter to help those in need are more focused and effective and are better placed to provide such services to help individuals and families in the community.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, why is the Ministry of Community Development not providing such shelters? What are the reservations? Secondly, does the Ministry of Community Development provide support in terms of building and operating costs to these VWOs who operate such halfway houses?

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: Sir, I have mentioned why the Government is not involved in the building of halfway houses. As I said earlier, it is because VWOs are doing a good job and they could cater to the needs of their clients better.

    With regard to the kind of help given by Government in terms of buildings and equipment, among the help given are tax exemptions for donations for charitable purposes, release of State land or premises with rental subsidy to cover market rental and of HDB premises at concessionary rental, waiver of development charges, assistance for recruitment of staff, free medical treatment to clients who are eligible and exemptions for COE and vehicle taxes.

    Crisis centres are currently not funded by Government as they do not fall under the category of "approved projects" for Government funding. My Ministry, however, is looking at the need for additional assistance to these organisations to enhance their work and services they are providing to help individuals in crisis. The review includes the possibility of them being put under the Government financial assistance schemes. In other words, we will help them in the set-up costs and also operating costs.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, is the Minister's assessment on the current number of halfway houses sufficient to house families who are in need? Because it was reported that families were turned away by halfway houses owing to lack of space.

Column: 570



     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: Sir, according to our statistics, the total occupancy for the six crisis centres that we now have - the seventh is in the pipeline - has not at any one time reached 100%. In other words, they have, at one time or other, some vacancies at their premises.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, may I have confirmation from the Minister that the Government is considering to bring projects like halfway houses into the so-called approved projects, thereby they will be eligible for financial assistance from the Government, especially the operating costs and recurrent costs?

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: As I said, we are reviewing the situation and we will make recommendations as appropriate.

INTERNATIONAL SCHOOLS IN SINGAPORE
(Non-admission of Singaporeans)


    5. Mr Lew Syn Pau asked the Minister for Education why Singaporeans are not permitted to send their children to International Schools in Singapore.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, international schools in Singapore are set up specifically to cater to the educational needs of the children of the expatriate community.

    Singapore citizens residing in Singapore should receive their education in our schools where citizenship education consistent with our national values and aspirations is taught. If they attend foreign system schools, they will miss out on the curricula and activities conducted in our schools which seek to inculcate in our students desirable social values and a sense of national identity.

     Mr Lew Syn Pau (Tanglin): Sir, I do not quite understand the policy because the Minister has decided not to make education compulsory in the first place, which means that, effectively, children can stay at home. But, at the same time, they cannot attend international schools. So I do not understand the inconsistency in the policy.

Column: 571



     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, there is no inconsistency. We want all our Singaporean children to attend school. We have not made education compulsory because there is no need to. Almost every child of school-going age is in school. The reason why we insist that they go to Singapore schools is for the purposes I have explained. We have our own curriculum. We have, for example, a bilingual policy. We also try to inculcate in our children certain values. International schools are meant for expatriates. For Singaporeans, we want them to go to our schools.

     Mr Lew Syn Pau: Sir, if for some reason like personal family circumstances, would the Minister be prepared to give a waiver on this policy and allow them to attend international schools?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Yes, we have done so in some cases. The majority of the children who go to these schools are either expatriates or they are children of mixed marriages, eg, European or American men married to local women. Their children may be allowed to attend international schools. There could be other cases of children with special problems, eg, they are autistic or they have other psychological problems, and if these schools offer special facilities, we may consider allowing them to go to these schools.

PERSONS WHO COMMITTED THEFT AND MADE FULL RESTITUTION
(Circumstances for withdrawal of charges)


    7. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Home Affairs what are the circumstances in which charges against persons who committed theft but had made full restitution will be withdrawn, and how many cases of such withdrawal were recorded since 1992.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, theft cases including shoplifting are seizable offences investigated by the Police. Upon completion of investigations, the Police will assess the evidence and the merits of the case. If there is sufficient evidence, the offender will be prosecuted in court unless there are merits in the case to withdraw the charge. In such a case, Police will seek concurrence from the Deputy Public Prosecutor (DPP) to administer a stern caution to the offender in lieu of prosecution.

    Sir, the rationale for cautioning an offender in lieu of prosecution is to allow him a second chance so that he can learn from his mistakes and change for the better. An offender may be considered for cautioning particularly if he has not been prosecuted in court or cautioned by the Police before or where there are mitigating circumstances leading to the commission of the offence such as in the case of a young offender.

    Police will evaluate the case as a whole, taking into consideration all the facts and circumstances. Making restitution is only one of the factors that Police will consider as a possible indication of remorse. However, making restitution by itself does not mean that the charge will be withdrawn.

Column: 573



    Sir, the Police does not have available records on the number of cases where the charge was withdrawn solely because restitution was made. Since 1995, there have been 1,123 cases of shoplifting and minor thefts where the offenders were cautioned and charges withdrawn against the offender. The majority of these cases are for shoplifting and the bulk of the offenders are minors.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I refer to the case of a British schoolboy, John David Raven, whose charge was withdrawn by the Attorney-General. I would like to know what were the merits of the case and under what circumstances was the charge withdrawn.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the case referred to by the Member is of a 18-year old British national who was charged for theft in July 1996. His counsel made representation where he expressed remorse for committing the offence and he also made full restitution to the victim. So the DPP, in accordance with normal guidelines, looked at it and handled it as a routine matter and withdrew the charge.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, what were the merits of the case? And what principles were involved in withdrawing the charge against the boy?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, as I said just now, the Police will look at all the circumstances of the case, particularly if the offender is a young person, like the case in question, and also the fact that he is a first offender. These were the circumstances. On top of that if restitution is made, as a factor, it is also considered in deciding whether or not to withdraw the charge.

NETS POINT-OF-SALE TERMINALS
(Installation of additional terminals at HDB Branch Offices)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Lau Ping Sum -

    8. To ask the Minister for National Development whether additional NETS Point-of-Sale terminals will be installed at Housing and Development Board Branch Offices to facilitate cashless payments.

Column: 574



     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Question No. 8, Sir.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, NETS is a convenient cashless mode of payment. HDB installed a NETS terminal at the Ang Mo Kio Branch Office in May 1988. Background

    Let me first give Members of this House some background information on the SDF. The SDF was established in 1979 under the Ministry of Finance to support and encourage the upgrading of skills of

Companies were required to contribute towards the Skills Development Fund through the payment of a certain percentage of their payroll for workers whose income falls below a stipulated cap. As the focus of the SDF was on training of workers to improve productivity, the SDF was subsequently transferred to the National Productivity Board. With the merger of the National Productivity Board and the Singapore Institute of Standards and Industrial Research to form the new PSB in April 1996, the SDF now comes under the administration of PSB.     The SDF has played an indispensable role of facilitating and encouraging Singapore workers to upgrade and acquire new skills. Since its inception, $731 million has been disbursed to support 2.8 million training places. In 1995 alone, 489,911 training places were committed under the SDF. Main objectives

    The Government needs to amend the SDL Act for two main reasons. Secondly, we want to ensure that SDF support for workers' training can continue uninterrupted during transitions of Government.

    With the proposed amendment to the SDL Act, the SDF will be transferred from the Government to PSB as a statutory board. PSB will be responsible for the management and administration of the Fund, with built-in Ministerial controls to prevent misuse of the Fund. Major amendments

    I will now describe in more detail the major amendments proposed in the Bill. There are two major amendments. First, to widen the definition of SDF beneficiaries, and second, to transfer the Fund from the Government to PSB.

    Under the existing SDL Act, the beneficiaries of SDF grants are restricted to "persons in employment" and retrenched persons. The present definition therefore caters only to workers in active employment and retrenched workers. Clause 4 of the Amendment Bill extends SDF beneficiaries to include first, persons "in the workforce", for example, the self-employed and contract workers; second, persons "preparing to join the workforce", for example, school-leavers; and third, persons rejoining the workforce, for example, housewives and retirees. About 270,000 persons, or 16% of the workforce, who are self-employed or unemployed stand to benefit from additional training opportunities arising from this wider definition. The revised definition will also facilitate a large pool of the economically inactive persons to enter or re-enter the workforce.

    The second major amendment relates to the transfer of the SDF from Government to PSB. The SDF is currently a Government fund. It becomes part of the reserves when the current Government's term of office ends. With an annual grant commitment of about $70 million, the SDF will encounter serious cash-flow problems if it is not able to tap on its reserves after a transition of Government, but has to rely solely on fresh levy collections.
